Field Guide

A Practical Reference for an Impractical Fish

How to (Respectfully) Spot a Tree Trout

Oncorhynchus arboris

The Rocky Mountain tree trout is best observed indirectly.

Despite decades of reported sightings, confirmed visual documentation remains elusive - owing not to rarity alone, but to the species' exceptional camouflage, arboreal habits, and apparent preference for remaining unobserved.

Identifying Signs of Presence

Rather than scanning branches for fish-shaped silhouettes, experienced observers recommend attending to secondary indicators, including:

  • Subtle branch jostling without wind
  • Isolated droplets falling from canopy pools on otherwise dry mornings
  • Momentary flashes of mottled orange or olive, quickly reabsorbed into bark texture
  • Invertebrate silence, particularly among aphids and beetles, suggesting recent predation

Many hikers report the unmistakable sound of "something wet reconsidering its choices" above them. While not diagnostic, this auditory cue appears frequently in credible accounts.

Preferred Habitat

Tree trout favor high-elevation coniferous forests where:

  • Streams intersect mature pine and fir stands
  • Epiphytic mats retain moisture
  • Fog drip sustains small canopy reservoirs

They are most active in early morning and late evening, particularly during seasonal transitions when movement between aquatic and arboreal environments increases.

Ethical Observation Guidelines

Tree trout are sensitive to disturbance. To minimize impact:

  • Do not shake branches "just to see"
  • Avoid climbing trees near streams
  • Refrain from tossing snacks upward, no matter how fish-like
  • Observe quietly and let uncertainty do the rest

Remember: the absence of confirmation is not failure - it is participation.

Common Misidentifications

Observed Phenomenon Likely Explanation
Pinecone falling straight down Gravity
Pinecone falling sideways Wind
Pinecone falling sideways with splash Possibly gravity + imagination
Sudden conviction you saw something Entirely normal
